title: Jeremy Corbyn comes out fighting while Theresa May hides in plain sight
text:

Well it seems Jeremy Corbyn has come out fighting while Theresa May is hiding in plain sight on the general election trail. 
Our Prime Minister has made much of her strong leadership and wrapped herself in a Union Jack like a Brexit Boudicca. 
Yet when it comes to taking the opportunity to debating her policies on TV against Corbyn she has decided to leave her chariot in the garage. 
And her every visit on the campaign trail is stage managed to the point of sterility with any person not ‘on message’ kept well away. 
Meanwhile Corbyn is at last being given the chance to talk about his policies and what he could do for the country whilst facing all comers. 
It’s an opportunity he has been rarely given since he became Labour leader two years ago which has seen him come under the most intense scrutiny. Prime Minster Theresa May gives a short speech and Q&A at GSK on April 21, 2017 in Maidenhead (Photo: PA) 
If May faced the same kind of scrutiny and was judged in the media on what her government had actually achieved and not what favours she can bestow upon newspaper proprietors I think the poll ratings would be significantly different. 
When she called a snap election it flew in the face of numerous promises she had made since she became PM not to. 
When Corbyn chose not to challenge her and instead back an early election it was described by some as ‘political suicide’ as he could not win. 
How cynical we have become. Forget having the courage of your convictions, only act if you believe you are 100% sure of winning. 
Well, here’s the thing. Although it’s a long shot May might not win the majority she craves, particularly if she carries on the way she is doing. Read More 
She’s trying to make the election about Brexit but the country isn’t as obsessed with Brexit as she thinks now the referendum has been held and we voted to leave. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn delivers a speech at Whitchurch High Street in Cardiff (Photo: PA) 
The majority of voters are much more concerned with a National Health Service in meltdown, a social care crisis, spiralling poverty, stagnating wages, benefits cuts, a state education system under siege and inequality at an historic low. 
The country is in a mess yet when May announced the snap election she spoke of standing by her record. 
I can’t think of one positive thing her government has achieved. And no wonder, looking at who holds the top jobs in her administration. 
You have a Chancellor, Philip Hammond, who doesn’t even know his own party’s manifesto commitments and a Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson, who wanders the world stage in this country’s name like Coco the clown. Read More How quietly, almost invisibly, the authorities are working to keep us safe 
And then there’s David Davis who has been in charge of Brexit negotiations since last year and who admitted only last month he hasn’t got a clue what the possible impact of Brexit on the country will be as he hasn’t looked into it. 
The Tories claim that Corbyn is unfit to run the country. Pots and kettles, as they say. Like us on Facebook
